text: what is the function to call on a `DataFrame` to say how big the `CSV.write` will be?

text: i dont think there is a function for that, unfortunately.

elements.text: i dont think there is a function for that, unfortunately.

text: I'd guess it isn't possible to know how big the file will be without actually making the file

elements.text: I'd guess it isn't possible to know how big the file will be without actually making the file

text: you could write it into an IOBuffer() and check the size of that

elements.text: you could write it into an IOBuffer() and check the size of that

text: well, actually, you can look at the size of an object, right? You can use `Base.summarysize(df)`, but I don't know exactly how that all works.

elements.text: well, actually, you can look at the size of an object, right? You can use
Base.summarysize(df)
, but I don't know exactly how that all works.

text:
Knowing it the size of the object won't tell you the since of the CSV.
E.g. 0.5 vs 0.125, both are 8 bytes as a float64 but the former is 3 bytes as a CSV entry, and the later is 5.

elements.text:
Knowing it the size of the object won't tell you the since of the CSV.
E.g. 0.5 vs 0.125, both are 8 bytes as a float64 but the former is 3 bytes as a CSV entry, and the later is 5.

text: That gives the size of the objects in memory, which is different from the size of the CSV

elements.text: That gives the size of the objects in memory, which is different from the size of the CSV

text: If one wanted to do better than an IOBuffer, then a custom subtype of IO that discards everything it is fed, but increments a count could be defined.

elements.text: If one wanted to do better than an IOBuffer, then a custom subtype of IO that discards everything it is fed, but increments a count could be defined.

text: If one was willing to accept an upper bound, that could probably be worked out from the types

elements.text: If one was willing to accept an upper bound, that could probably be worked out from the types

text: You could estimate from a fixed-size sample

elements.text: You could estimate from a fixed-size sample

text: Probably the easiest way, if you really needed to know before hand how big a file would be, would be to create a custom IO type that just kept track of how many bytes were written finit and ignored actually writing anything.

elements.text: Probably the easiest way, if you really needed to know before hand how big a file would be, would be to create a custom IO type that just kept track of how many bytes were written finit and ignored actually writing anything.
